Posts.Content: Hubby woke up from surgery with the sticky holder already attached. Hospital also sent him home with two extras just in case but the original one held on perfectly all week through daily showers. They also sent him home with a few Chux pads for the bed - the incision sites did bleed a bit especially the drain site that was removed just before he was discharged. The large drainage bag had a plastic clip attached to it with a doubled rubber band so that the clip could be easily repositioned anywhere along the length of the tube. We attached the clip to the side of the mattress - on the bottom sheet - to prevent the weight of the bag from pulling on the tubing. Most of the work during the week he had the catheter was in changing from the large bag to the leg bag every morning and cleaning everything thoroughly and then changing back at bedtime - a job which fell to me of course! If you can avoid that it would really make it easier. Hubby wanted the smaller bag on during the day - but then would want to lie down and rest a couple times each day and since he was wearing the sweat pants we bought in advance that made it a problematic since he needed the bag to hang below his body. I think pants that snap along the sides would work much better - or no pants at all! Since he had the catheter during Christmas week it was different. Our daughter was home staying with us for the holidays and we had Christmas dinner for the whole extended family at our home as well. So the bathrobe wasn't going to work for him because of the timing of surgery. Julie

Right mid 3+4=7 (20% G4) with intraductal component Left mid 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Right apex 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Left apex negative for carcinoma. RALP 12-21-18 Dr. Nadler at Northwestern Memorial/Chicago 3+4=7 (30% G4 component) (Grade group 2). Bilat. acinar adenocarcinoma, organ-confined, 5.4% of examined tissue. EPE-, SM-, SVI-, LNI-, PNI+ 1.5 cm nodule at right posterior mid pT2pN0 Post RALP PSA .01 1-19

Posts.Content: You are not alone. Hubby had surgery 3 weeks ago and this is an ongoing issue for him as well. He came home from the hospital on no opioids - just tylenol and ibuprofen - so I assumed he'd by fine by now. I was thinking the stool softeners the dr prescribed were for any residual effects from the pain meds used during his surgery but apparently there is much more involved here... He has been taking the stool softener/laxative combo pills all day every day but even that isn't always enough. I had to run to walgreens yesterday for a box of fleet enemas which finally provided some relief. Is this related to the anesthesia or the surgery itself? Julie

Posts.Title: Post RALP BM problems

Posts.Content: Thanks so much for the replies Chuck and Djin! Chuck - I've edited my signature to remove all the extra "leasons" - that should help! All margins were negative thankfully. About the change in Gleason score - I mentioned the grade change from biopsy to surgical pathology to the nurse who was about to remove Bob's catheter since it was such a significant change. The nurse then announced that many 3+4 patients don't even opt for surgery but choose active surveillance instead. I knew that, having read so much about treatment options here, but was very surprised that a nurse would tell a patient who'd just had RP that, in essence, perhaps he hadn't needed to. I know Bob's decision would have been surgery if the biopsy had indicated either 3+4 (G4 was 30%) or 3+3 but the nurse didn't know that. Some patients might have been pretty upset to hear that during their catheter removal! Djin- We are very optimistic about the final path report but nervous as well about the first couple PSA tests... I forgot to mention that Bob didn't find out about Kegel exercises until two days before surgery when we attended a class at the hospital taught by a prostate cancer educator. I'd tried to explain the exercises to him in advance but he really didn't listen to me - until the nurse stressed their importance. By then he only had one day to practice! He is doing them now though. I found him videos on youtube that helped him get "it" as well. About the tumor's size - big prostate I think? I ran out of room to add to the signature from the final pathology report the size: Weight: 73 grams Size: 5 x 4.7 x 4.5 cm And I wanted to include the MRI report since there was certainly no room in the signature for that! PROCEDURE: MRI PROSTATE W WO CONTRAST W PET. HISTORY: Elevated PSA: 4.79 on 8/28/2018. Status post biopsy on 11/13/2018 with multifocal adenocarcinoma including Gleason 4+4 in the right base. TECHNIQUE: Multi-parametric 3.0 Tesla MRI was performed using a torso phased-array coil, including multiplanar T2-weighted images, axial T1-weighted images, axial diffusion-weighted images, and volumetric dynamic post-contrast images of the prostate. Axial in-and-opposed-phase gradient-echo T1-weighted images and pre- and post-contrast fat-suppressed gradient-echo T1-weighted images of the entire pelvis were also obtained using the "Prostate with contrast" protocol. COMPARISON: None available. FINDINGS: Prostate size: 5.1 [CC] x 4.3 [AP] x 5.3 [transverse] cm for an overall volume of 60.4 cc. PSA density: 0.08 Membranous urethra length: 1.5 cm. There is diffuse intrinsic T1 hyperintensity throughout the peripheral zones and also scattered within the transitional zones, likely representing blood products from recent biopsy, significantly limiting evaluation. There is also a moderate amount of air within the rectum, which limits evaluation of the DWI/ADC sequences. Tumor localization: Lesion 1 PI-RADS assessment category: 4, High probability Appearance on T2-weighted images: 4, circumscribed, homogeneous moderate hypointense focus/mass confined to prostate and <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on diffusion-weighted images: 4, focal markedly hypointense on ADC and markedly hyperintense on high b value DWI; <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on dynamic post-contrast images: Positive - Focal enhancement directly corresponding to the suspicious finding with early or contemporaneous enhancement to normal prostate Size: 0.9 x 0.4 cm, series 15 image 15 (T2) Side: Right. Zone: Peripheral Level of prostate: Midgland Location within transverse plane: Posteromedial Extraprostatic extension: Abuts the prostatic capsule Lesion 2 PI-RADS assessment category: 4, High probability Appearance on T2-weighted images: 4, circumscribed, homogeneous moderate hypointense focus/mass confined to prostate and <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on diffusion-weighted images: 4, focal markedly hypointense on ADC and markedly hyperintense on high b value DWI; <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on dynamic post-contrast images: Positive - Focal enhancement directly corresponding to the suspicious finding with early or contemporaneous enhancement to normal prostate Size: 0.8 x 0.3 cm, series 15 image 14 (T2) Side: Right. Zone: Peripheral Level of prostate: Midgland Location within transverse plane: Posteromedial Extraprostatic extension: Abuts the prostatic capsule Lesion 3 PI-RADS assessment category: 3, Intermediate probability Appearance on T2-weighted images: 3, heterogeneous signal intensity or non-circumscribed, rounded, moderate hypointensity Appearance on diffusion-weighted images: 3, focal mildly/moderately hypointense on ADC and isointense/mildly hyperintense on high b value DWI Appearance on dynamic post-contrast images: Negative - No early enhancement Size: 0.7 x 0.3 cm, series 15 image 15 (T2) Side: Left. Zone: Peripheral Level of prostate: Midgland Location within transverse plane: Posteromedial Extraprostatic extension: Abuts the prostatic capsule Additional peripheral zone findings: Linear or wedge-areas of decreased signal on T2-weighted imaging with associated diffuse increased perfusion, suggestive of prostatitis. Additional transition zone findings: Enlarged and heterogeneous with circumscribed nodules consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia. Extraprostatic extension: None Seminal vesicle invasion: None. Lymph nodes: No pelvic lymphadenopathy. Osseous structures: No aggressive osseous lesion. Additional findings: The urinary bladder is decompressed. The MRI images of the concurrent PET/MRI study demonstrated no enlarged lymph nodes, suspicious osseous lesion, or areas of restricted diffusion. IMPRESSION: Diffuse intrinsic T1 hyperintensity throughout the prostate gland, likely represent blood products from recent biopsy, and significantly limits evaluation and air limiting the diffusion images. 0.9 x 0.4 cm right posteromedial midgland peripheral zone lesion, corresponding to an assessment category of PIRADS 4 - High (clinically significant cancer is likely to be present). 0.8 x 0.3 cm right posteromedial midgland peripheral zone lesion, corresponding to an assessment category of PIRADS 4 - High (clinically significant cancer is likely to be present). 0.7 x 0.3 cm left posteromedial midgland peripheral zone lesion, corresponding to an assessment category of PIRADS 3 - Intermediate (the presence of clinically significant cancer is equivocal). Findings compatible with prostatitis and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Right mid 3+4=7 (20% G4) with intraductal component Left mid 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Right apex 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Left apex negative for carcinoma. RALP 12-21-18 Dr. Nadler at Northwestern Memorial/Chicago 3+4=7 (30% G4 component) (Grade group 2). Bilat. acinar adenocarcinoma, organ-confined, 5.4% of examined tissue. Posts.Title: ~Intro and THANK YOU to ALL~

Posts.Content: I found this forum a week or so ago and have read many hundreds of posts here since then. So much helpful information here and I am so grateful to all who have shared their experiences and expertise. Took me a few tries to get the signature short enough to "fit" so perhaps there is more editing I should do? After hubby's biopsy came back at 4+4 I was very worried the final pathology report would be worse - having seen many others post a change in Gleason after surgery when the biopsy needle didn't hit the worst areas. Also the repeated references to "with intraductal component" in the biopsy report led me to fear this was a reference to IDC-P which I'd read was rare and definitely not what you'd want to see in a pathology report. He had an MRI a few weeks later but I didn't have enough room in the signature section to post that info. Surgery was robotic 8 days ago on the 21st at Northwestern Memorial in Chicago. Then the wait for the path report.... I could see that some here had received their path reports within a few days so after six days had passed I couldn't take it anymore and messaged the dr's office through the portal to ask if the report was available yet and they posted it online later that day. I was really preparing myself to see a 5 in the final report so was quite shocked when the final path showed 3+4 acinar adenocarcinoma with no mention of any intraductal anything! Yesterday the nurse took the catheter out. No filling the bladder with saline and asking him to try to stop the stream first. I'd expected that to happen after reading about it here. Instead the nurse just withdrew the saline via syringe and slipped the tubing out. Hubby grimaced for a second during the procedure but that was it. I'd ordered a free sample kit of Tena pads in advance - as recommended by a member here. The nurse gave him a pull-up Depends to put on immediately and another to take home. I added the maximum Tena pad inside the Depends for the short car ride home. Unfortunately all the surgeon's office stocked was size XL and way too big for hubby. I was worried about leakage from the sides so dropped him at home and went to Walgreens for supplies. We had a few Chux pads for the bed ready - the hospital had sent us home with those. At Walgreens I bought a huge double pack of Depends Flex Fit and a 52 count size of their maximum pads. Then I ordered a washable bed pad and some jockey shorts with 5% spandex (another suggestion by a member here!) from Amazon. Yesterday afternoon after the catheter was removed hubby said he felt dry and didn't think he was leaking which seemed odd. He tried urinating and stopping his flow (as I told him some here had done in the dr's office just before the catheter was removed) and he said he was able to do that. At bedtime he changed into his new gear from Walgreens - a properly fitting Depends pull-up along with a Depends pad - and I made sure he was properly positioned on top of the Chux pad. Overnight he got up several times to urinate and had no leaking in-between. Today is the same so far - no leaking at all. I'm hoping this is a good harbinger for the future? Or is this possibly just a short-term situation? This is certainly not at all what we expected. Surgeon had said a return to continence would take up to a year - and would be a slow process requiring lots of patience. Said about a 5% chance it wouldn't return after that time and would require another procedure - an artificial sphincter I assume. Thanks to everyone for all your info and any feedback!

Right mid 3+4=7 (20% G4) with intraductal component Left mid 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Right apex 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Left apex negative for carcinoma. RALP 12-21-18 Dr. Nadler at Northwestern Memorial/Chicago 3+4=7 (30% G4 component) (Grade group 2). Bilat. acinar adenocarcinoma, organ-confined, 5.4% of examined tissue. EPE-, SM-, SVI-, LNI-, PNI+ 1.5 cm nodule at right posterior mid pT2pN0 Post RALP PSA .01 1-19
Posts.Title: ~Intro and THANK YOU to ALL~

Posts.Content: Chuck - He did call and speak to a nurse. I think the surgeon is off on vacation for the holidays. He gave Bob his cell number at the first appointment and typically answers texts (imessages) quickly but when Bob messaged him a few days after surgery with a question we could see the imessage was still green/undelivered. Probably in Europe or off on an island somewhere. The nurse said it was nothing to worry about. Seems to be getting better this evening as well. Thanks again! Julie

Posts.Title: ~Intro and THANK YOU to ALL~

Posts.Content: Chuck and Another - Thanks so much to both of you for the positive feedback! I saw a reference to the number of lesions being an issue with potential AS citing a recent Johns Hopkins study here: https://sperlingprostatecenter.com/g...-surveillance/ I believe I also saw a reference somewhere about possible AS for G3+4 IF LESS than 6% G4. But Bob had 30% G4 and would NOT have decided on AS in either case - it's not in his nature. With the catheter out for the last 2 days/nights things continue to look promising with continence! However he'd had a little blood in his urine since then - just at the very start of urination. I told him to call the dr's office to check to make sure it's related to the catheter removal and nothing to worry about but so far he isn't concerned enough to call. Perhaps in the morning if it hasn't stopped by then... Julie

I forgot to mention that Bob didn't find out about Kegel exercises until two days before surgery when we attended a class at the hospital taught by a prostate cancer educator. I'd tried to explain the exercises to him in advance but he really didn't listen to me - until the nurse stressed their importance. By then he only had one day to practice! He is doing them now though. I found him videos on youtube that helped him get "it" as well. About the tumor's size - big prostate I think? I ran out of room to add to the signature from the final pathology report the size: Weight: 73 grams Size: 5 x 4.7 x 4.5 cm And I wanted to include the MRI report since there was certainly no room in the signature for that! PROCEDURE: MRI PROSTATE W WO CONTRAST W PET. HISTORY: Elevated PSA: 4.79 on 8/28/2018. Status post biopsy on 11/13/2018 with multifocal adenocarcinoma including Gleason 4+4 in the right base. TECHNIQUE: Multi-parametric 3.0 Tesla MRI was performed using a torso phased-array coil, including multiplanar T2-weighted images, axial T1-weighted images, axial diffusion-weighted images, and volumetric dynamic post-contrast images of the prostate. Axial in-and-opposed-phase gradient-echo T1-weighted images and pre- and post-contrast fat-suppressed gradient-echo T1-weighted images of the entire pelvis were also obtained using the "Prostate with contrast" protocol. COMPARISON: None available. FINDINGS: Prostate size: 5.1 [CC] x 4.3 [AP] x 5.3 [transverse] cm for an overall volume of 60.4 cc. PSA density: 0.08 Membranous urethra length: 1.5 cm. There is diffuse intrinsic T1 hyperintensity throughout the peripheral zones and also scattered within the transitional zones, likely representing blood products from recent biopsy, significantly limiting evaluation. There is also a moderate amount of air within the rectum, which limits evaluation of the DWI/ADC sequences. Tumor localization: Lesion 1 PI-RADS assessment category: 4, High probability Appearance on T2-weighted images: 4, circumscribed, homogeneous moderate hypointense focus/mass confined to prostate and <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on diffusion-weighted images: 4, focal markedly hypointense on ADC and markedly hyperintense on high b value DWI; <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on dynamic post-contrast images: Positive - Focal enhancement directly corresponding to the suspicious finding with early or contemporaneous enhancement to normal prostate Size: 0.9 x 0.4 cm, series 15 image 15 (T2) Side: Right. Zone: Peripheral Level of prostate: Midgland Location within transverse plane: Posteromedial Extraprostatic extension: Abuts the prostatic capsule Lesion 2 PI-RADS assessment category: 4, High probability Appearance on T2-weighted images: 4, circumscribed, homogeneous moderate hypointense focus/mass confined to prostate and <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on diffusion-weighted images: 4, focal markedly hypointense on ADC and markedly hyperintense on high b value DWI; <1.5 cm in greatest dimension Appearance on dynamic post-contrast images: Positive - Focal enhancement directly corresponding to the suspicious finding with early or contemporaneous enhancement to normal prostate Size: 0.8 x 0.3 cm, series 15 image 14 (T2) Side: Right. Zone: Peripheral Level of prostate: Midgland Location within transverse plane: Posteromedial Extraprostatic extension: Abuts the prostatic capsule Lesion 3 PI-RADS assessment category: 3, Intermediate probability Appearance on T2-weighted images: 3, heterogeneous signal intensity or non-circumscribed, rounded, moderate hypointensity Appearance on diffusion-weighted images: 3, focal mildly/moderately hypointense on ADC and isointense/mildly hyperintense on high b value DWI Appearance on dynamic post-contrast images: Negative - No early enhancement Size: 0.7 x 0.3 cm, series 15 image 15 (T2) Side: Left. Zone: Peripheral Level of prostate: Midgland Location within transverse plane: Posteromedial Extraprostatic extension: Abuts the prostatic capsule Additional peripheral zone findings: Linear or wedge-areas of decreased signal on T2-weighted imaging with associated diffuse increased perfusion, suggestive of prostatitis. Additional transition zone findings: Enlarged and heterogeneous with circumscribed nodules consistent with benign prostatic hyperplasia. Extraprostatic extension: None Seminal vesicle invasion: None. Lymph nodes: No pelvic lymphadenopathy. Osseous structures: No aggressive osseous lesion. Additional findings: The urinary bladder is decompressed. The MRI images of the concurrent PET/MRI study demonstrated no enlarged lymph nodes, suspicious osseous lesion, or areas of restricted diffusion. IMPRESSION: Diffuse intrinsic T1 hyperintensity throughout the prostate gland, likely represent blood products from recent biopsy, and significantly limits evaluation and air limiting the diffusion images. 0.9 x 0.4 cm right posteromedial midgland peripheral zone lesion, corresponding to an assessment category of PIRADS 4 - High (clinically significant cancer is likely to be present). 0.8 x 0.3 cm right posteromedial midgland peripheral zone lesion, corresponding to an assessment category of PIRADS 4 - High (clinically significant cancer is likely to be present). 0.7 x 0.3 cm left posteromedial midgland peripheral zone lesion, corresponding to an assessment category of PIRADS 3 - Intermediate (the presence of clinically significant cancer is equivocal). Findings compatible with prostatitis and benign prostatic hyperplasia.
Posts.Signature: Age 67 PSA 4.2 5-18 PSA 4.79 8-18 DRE normal Biopsy 11-13-18: Right base 4+4=8 (Grade group 4) Left base 3+3=6 involving 5% of 1 of 3 cores. Right mid 3+4=7 (20% G4) with intraductal component Left mid 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Right apex 3+4=7 (40% G4) with intraductal component Left apex negative for carcinoma. RALP 12-21-18 Dr. Nadler at Northwestern Memorial/Chicago 3+4=7 (30% G4 component) (Grade group 2). Bilat. acinar adenocarcinoma, organ-confined, 5.4% of examined tissue. We have hubby's one month post-prostatectomy followup appointment in a few weeks and I will insist on the Decipher test if the dr. doesn't beat me to it. More info is always better - especially with hubby's biopsy reference to several specimens having an "intraductal component." Julie

Posts.Title: Decipher Testing

Posts.Content: All the research studies I've read about the first PSA test reference waiting for 3 months for the PSA to clear the system. I wasn't thrilled that hubby's test was scheduled for six weeks post RALP by his urologist because of that. I'm wondering if this is related to pairing the test with a post-op visit with the surgeon for some reason? Meaning perhaps it is considered standard protocol to have a post-op checkup at that point after RALP to check incision healing etc - and because of that some drs do the PSA at the same time to save patients a visit? Julie

And we should all move to Miami as well. Or at least winter there. We are heading there in a few weeks to escape frigid Chicagoland where the low tomorrow will be 18 below 0 and the HIGH on Wednesday is -12 with a low of -21! Julie

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by HighlanderCFH Shivering along with you in the Chicago area! Even a zero PSA reading will show some micro-fluxuations if it went to 3 digits, which is meaningless. So the 2-digit PSA reading is fine. Not a bad idea to test again in 3 months for peace of mind. Thanks so much @HighlanderCFH! We are so grateful for all your help, advice and support. Sorry to hear you are freezing along with us here in Chicagoland - looks like the weekend will be a complete reversal though!

Posts.Title: ~6 Week Post-RALP PSA results~

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by DjinTonic Congrats! That's Bob's ticket to Club Zero! Well done! You've both come a long way. When the first PSA test post-surgery comes back "essentially zero" it marks the end of the very taxing period from the diagnosis bombshell through treatment-decision confusion and then surgery. Time to smile and relax while the body heals. A two-decimal PSA test is fine. Test every three months if that gives you both comfort, but if it holds steady, and your doc says 6-month testing is fine, consider going to that to take your mind off of this for longer stretches. Thanks so much @DjinTonic! Your feedback is always so helpful and is much appreciated. We are so glad he has joined the club!

Posts.Content: Hubby had his first PSA test yesterday after RALP on Dec 21st and the results popped up on My Chart this morning: .01! Dr. tested only to two digits which I think is best for my husband who worries constantly about every aspect of his health. Good news and a great distraction from the current weather here in Chicagoland where it's forecast to drop to -22 again tonight for the second night in a row. Dr. said hubby should retest in 3-6 months. Definitely we'll do 3 NOT 6. Julie

DoctorRecommended.Sample: I was thinking the stool softeners the dr prescribed were for any residual effects from the pain meds used during his surgery but apparently there is much more involved here... He has been taking the stool softener/laxative combo pills all day every day but even that isn't always enough....He came home from the hospital on no opioids - just tylenol and ibuprofen - so I assumed he'd by fine by now. I was thinking the stool softeners the dr prescribed were for any residual effects from the pain meds used during his surgery but apparently there is much more involved here......
